prompt: Create a mini course on Git basics

console_output: [Orchestral]   Lesson 1/10: Introduction to Version Control and Git Architecture
[Orchestral]   Lesson 2/10: Setting Up and Initializing Repositories
[Orchestral]   Lesson 4/10: Managing Changes and Undoing Mistakes
[Orchestral]   Lesson 6/10: Advanced Merging and Conflict Resolution
[Orchestral]   Lesson 7/10: Remote Collaboration: Pushing and Pulling
[Orchestral]   Lesson 8/10: The Power of Rebasing and Rewriting History
[Orchestral]   Lesson 10/10: Collaborative Workflows and Pull Requests

syllabus.course_title: Mastering Git: From First Commit to Collaborative Workflows
syllabus.course_objective: To provide learners with a comprehensive understanding of version control principles, practical command-line proficiency, and the ability to manage complex collaborative software projects using Git.

lessons.title: Introduction to Version Control and Git Architecture
objectives: Explain the fundamental differences between Centralized Version Control Systems (CVCS) and Distributed Version Control Systems (DVCS).
Identify and describe the three main states of Git: the working directory, the staging area (index), and the git directory (repository).
Conceptualize the data flow between local and remote environments.
content_outline: Evolution of Version Control: From local file copying to Centralized systems (e.g., SVN, Perforce).
The DVCS Revolution: Highlighting Git's design by Linus Torvalds for the Linux kernel development.
Git's Philosophy: Snapshot-based tracking vs. Delta-based tracking.
The Three Stages: Working Directory (untracked/modified), Staging Area (prepared for commit), and Repository (committed snapshots).
The Lifecycle of a File: Untracked, Unmodified, Modified, and Staged states.
Local vs. Remote: Understanding that every developer has a full copy of the history and how 'push/pull' bridge the gap.
activities: Comparative Analysis: A group discussion mapping the failure points of a single central server vs. a distributed network.
Diagram Mapping: Sketching the 'Git Trinity' and labeling the commands (add, commit, checkout) that move files between stages.
Terminal Observation: Running 'git init' and 'git status' to observe how Git perceives a brand new file in a local environment.
resources: Pro Git Book (Chacon & Straub) - Chapters 1.1 to 1.3
Git Documentation: 'Getting Started - About Version Control'
Visualizing Git (Interactive Web Tool)
Command Line Interface (Linux, macOS, or Git Bash for Windows)
citations: Chacon, S., & Straub, B. (2014). Pro Git (2nd ed.). Apress.
Spinellis, D. (2012). Version Control Systems. IEEE Software, 29(5), 100-101.
Torvalds, L. (2005). Git: A distributed version control system. Software management principles.

lessons.title: Setting Up and Initializing Repositories
objectives: Configure global user identity (name and email) for Git commits.
Create new local repositories from scratch using initialization commands.
Clone existing remote repositories to a local machine.
Identify and understand the purpose of the hidden .git directory.
content_outline: Introduction to Git Configuration: Scope levels (system, global, local).
Identity Setup: Using 'git config' to set user.name and user.email.
Project Initialization: Converting a standard directory into a Git repository with 'git init'.
Anatomy of a Repository: Exploring the hidden .git folder and its role in version tracking.
Remote Collaboration: Fetching projects using 'git clone' and understanding the relationship between local and remote copies.
activities: Terminal Setup: Run 'git config --global' commands and verify settings using 'git config --list'.
Local Creation: Create a folder named 'my-first-repo', initialize it, and use 'ls -a' to reveal the .git directory.
Cloning Lab: Clone a public repository from GitHub (e.g., a simple 'hello-world' project) to observe automatic remote linking.
resources: Command line interface (Terminal or Git Bash)
Official Git Documentation (git-scm.com/docs)
Pro Git Book, Chapter 1.6: First-Time Git Setup
GitHub public repository URL for cloning practice
citations: Chacon, S., & Straub, B. (2014). Pro Git. Apress.
Git project contributors. (2023). Git Reference Manual: git-config, git-init, git-clone documentation.

lessons.title: The Basic Git Workflow
objectives: Track file changes through the staging lifecycle
Write effective commit messages
Navigate file status and history within a local repository
content_outline: Introduction to the Three States: Working Directory, Staging Area, and Git Directory
Inspecting the repository state with 'git status'
The Staging Process: Moving changes from working directory to index using 'git add'
Snapshotting Changes: Using 'git commit' to record staged updates
History Visualization: Reviewing the project timeline with 'git log'
Best practices for atomic commits and the anatomy of a good commit message
activities: Interactive Demo: Creating a new text file and tracking its lifecycle from untracked to committed
Code Lab: Staging specific files vs. all files (git add <file> vs git add .)
Peer Review: Writing and critiquing commit messages based on the 'Imperative Mood' standard
Log Exploration: Using flags like --oneline and --graph to visualize branching history
resources: Git Documentation: 2.2 Git Basics - Recording Changes to the Repository
Terminal/Command Line interface
Visual Studio Code or preferred Text Editor
Pro Git Book by Scott Chacon and Ben Straub
citations: Chacon, S., & Straub, B. (2014). Pro Git. Apress.
Atlassian Bitbucket. (n.d.). Git Workflow: Staging Area and Commits.
The Git Project. (2023). Reference Guide: git-status, git-add, git-commit.

lessons.title: Managing Changes and Undoing Mistakes
objectives: Compare different versions of files using inspection commands
Differentiate between soft, mixed, and hard resets
Recover from errors by safely reverting commits or undoing local changes
content_outline: Introduction to Inspection: Using git diff to see unstaged vs. staged changes
Comparing commits: Using git diff with commit hashes and HEAD
Undoing local work: Using git checkout and git restore to discard changes in the working directory
The 3 Flavors of git reset: Soft (keep changes staged), Mixed (keep changes unstaged), and Hard (discard all changes)
Public Correction: Creating 'inverse' commits with git revert to maintain project history
Safety first: When to use reset vs. revert in collaborative environments
activities: Difference Discovery: Modify a file and use git diff to identify specific line changes before staging
The Great Undo: Stage a file, then use git reset to unstage it without losing the work
Time Travel Lab: Perform a git hard reset to a previous commit, then use the reflog to recover a 'lost' state
Collaborative Fix: Simulate a shared history error and use git revert to fix it without burning the commit history
resources: Visual Git Reference: Reset vs Revert diagrams
Git Documentation: Reference for git-reset and git-revert
Interactive Terminal: Git Bash or VS Code Integrated Terminal
citations: Chacon, S., & Straub, B. (2014). Pro Git. Apress.
Atlassian Bitbucket Tutorials: Undoing Changes.
Git SCM Manual. (n.d.). git-reset Documentation.

lessons.title: Branching Fundamentals
objectives: Create and navigate branches for feature development
Understand the role of the HEAD pointer in Git
Implement a basic feature-branching workflow
Execute a fundamental fast-forward merge
content_outline: Definition of a branch as a pointer to a commit
The role of HEAD as the 'active' pointer
Creating branches with 'git branch <name>'
Switching contexts using 'git switch' (and the legacy 'git checkout')
The 'Feature Branch' strategy: isolating development from 'main'
Introduction to merging: Integrating changes back into the primary line
Visualizing the commit graph during branching operations
activities: Interactive visualization: Mapping out HEAD movement on a whiteboard or digital tool
CLI Lab: Create a branch called 'feature-login', make a commit, and observe the divergence from 'main'
The 'Context Switch' challenge: Modify a file in one branch, switch to another, and observe the file system changes
Manual Merge: Perform a fast-forward merge from 'feature-login' into 'main' and delete the obsolete branch
resources: Git Documentation: 3.1 Git Branching - Branches in a Nutshell
Visualizing Git (online interactive tool)
Local terminal/bash environment
Sample text repository for modification
citations: Chacon, S., & Straub, B. (2014). Pro Git (2nd ed.). Apress.
Atlassian Bitbucket. (n.d.). Git Branching Tutorial.
Official Git Documentation (git-scm.com/docs).

lessons.title: Advanced Merging and Conflict Resolution
objectives: Distinguish between fast-forward and three-way (recursive) merge strategies
Interpret and resolve manual merge conflict markers within source code
Utilize safety commands like git merge --abort to manage failed merges
Identify best practices for maintaining a clean and linear project history
content_outline: Understanding Merge Strategies: The Fast-Forward Merge vs. The Merge Commit (Three-way merge)
Anatomy of a Conflict: Why they happen and how Git flags them
The Resolution Workflow: Identifying markers (<<<<, ====, >>>>), editing files, and staging results
Emergency Procedures: Using git merge --abort to reset state
Tooling: Overview of visual merge tools (mergetool) vs. manual text editing
Workflow Hygiene: Frequent pulling, small commits, and communication
activities: Simulation: Create a 'Feature' branch and a 'Main' branch, edit the same line in both, and trigger a merge conflict locally
Conflict Scavenger Hunt: Manually edit a file containing conflict markers to keep specific changes from both branches
Strategy Comparison: Execute a fast-forward merge and then use the --no-ff flag to see the difference in the git log graph
Command Line Rescue: Initiate a messy merge and successfully use the abort command to return to a clean working directory
resources: Git SCM Documentation: Basic Merging and Branching
Visualizing Git: Interactive D3-based branching simulator
VS Code Integrated Source Control Guide for Merge Conflicts
citations: Chacon, S., & Straub, B. (2014). Pro Git (2nd ed.). Apress.
Atlassian Bitbucket Tutorials: Git Merge Conflicts (https://www.atlassian.com/git/tutorials/using-branches/merge-conflicts)
Git Documentation: git-merge (https://git-scm.com/docs/git-merge)

lessons.title: Remote Collaboration: Pushing and Pulling
objectives: Synchronize local work with remote servers like GitHub/GitLab
Manage remote tracking branches
Differentiate between git fetch and git pull operations
Configure upstream tracking for seamless synchronization
content_outline: Introduction to Remote Repositories: Connecting local git to the cloud
Managing Remotes: Adding, renaming, and removing remote nicknames (origin)
Uploading Changes: Using git push to send local commits to a server
Downloading Changes: The two-step process of git fetch and git merge
Automated Updates: Using git pull as a combined command
Upstream Tracking: Setting -u or --set-upstream to link local and remote branches
Conflicts in Remote Sync: Introduction to common push/pull rejection scenarios
activities: Remote Setup: Create a repository on GitHub/GitLab and link it to a local folder using 'git remote add origin'
The First Push: Push the 'main' branch to the remote server using the '-u' flag
Simulated Collaboration: Use the web interface to edit a file, then perform a 'git pull' locally to synchronize
Fetch vs. Pull Lab: Execute 'git fetch' and inspect 'origin/main' before manually merging into the local branch
resources: Git Documentation: Working with Remotes (git-scm.com)
GitHub Guides: Getting Started with Remote Repositories
Interactive Terminal: Git Bash or Visual Studio Code Integrated Terminal
citations: Chacon, S., & Straub, B. (2014). Pro Git (2nd ed.). Apress.
GitHub Docs. (2023). Managing remote repositories.
Atlassian Bitbucket Tutorials. (2023). Syncing repositories: git fetch, pull, and push.

lessons.title: The Power of Rebasing and Rewriting History
objectives: Differentiate between merging and rebasing workflows
Use standard rebase to maintain a linear project history
Execute an interactive rebase to squash, reword, and drop commits
Identify when it is unsafe to rebase based on the Golden Rule of Rebasing
content_outline: Introduction to git rebase: Moving the base of a branch
Rebase vs. Merge: Linear history vs. preservation of context
The Golden Rule of Rebasing: Never rebase public branches
Interactive Rebase (git rebase -i): Understanding the todo list
Rewriting history commands: pick, reword, edit, squash, fixup, and drop
Resolving conflicts during a rebase process
Force pushing (git push --force-with-lease) after rewriting history
activities: Standard Rebase Exercise: Rebase a feature branch onto an updated main branch to eliminate merge commits
Interactive Workshop: Take a branch with 'messy' commits (e.g., 'work in progress', 'typo fix') and squash them into a single clean feature commit
Conflict Resolution Lab: Deliberately trigger and resolve a conflict during a rebase to practice using --continue and --abort
Group Discussion: Evaluate scenarios to determine if rebasing or merging is the appropriate strategy
resources: Git Documentation: Rewriting History (git-scm.com)
Visualizing Git: Interactive online rebase simulator
Terminal/CLI with a sample 'dirty' repository for practice
Cheat sheet: Interactive Rebase commands overview
citations: Chacon, S., & Straub, B. (2014). Pro Git. Apress.
Atlassian Bitbucket Tutorials: Merging vs. Rebasing.
Git-SCM Reference: git-rebase documentation.

lessons.title: Stashing, Tagging, and Searching
objectives: Temporarily store uncommitted work without committing to the branch
Mark specific release points or milestones in the project history
Utilize built-in search tools to locate specific code or metadata
content_outline: Introduction to Git Stash: Handling context switches and cleaning a dirty working directory
Managing the Stash Stack: push, pop, apply, list, and clear
Identifying Milestones: The difference between Lightweight and Annotated tags
Tag Management: Creating, listing, and pushing tags to remote repositories
Effective Searching: Using 'git grep' for content and 'git show' for object inspection
activities: Context Switch Simulation: Create changes, stash them to pull an urgent update, then restore the stash
Release Labeling: Create an annotated tag 'v1.0' with a message and push it to a mock remote
Code Audit: Use 'git grep' to find all occurrences of a specific function name across the codebase
Inspection Exercise: Use 'git show' to examine the metadata of a specific tag and commit
resources: Official Git Documentation (git-scm.com/docs)
Pro Git Book: Chapter 7.3 Stashing and Cleaning
Pro Git Book: Chapter 2.6 Tagging
Terminal/CLI with Git installed
citations: Chacon, S., & Straub, B. (2014). Pro Git. Apress.
Git Documentation Team. (2023). Git-stash Documentation.
Git Documentation Team. (2023). Git-tag Documentation.

lessons.title: Collaborative Workflows and Pull Requests
objectives: Execute a full Gitflow or GitHub flow lifecycle including feature branching and merging
Participate in constructive code reviews via Pull Requests (PRs)
Configure project-specific .gitignore files to manage environment-sensitive data
Demonstrate collaborative proficiency through a final integrated project build
content_outline: Introduction to Workflow Patterns: Forking (Open Source) vs. Shared Repository Branching (Internal Teams)
Deep Dive into GitHub Flow: Feature branches, PR creation, and the 'Ship/Show/Ask' philosophy
Principles of Pull Request Etiquette: Writing meaningful descriptions and responding to feedback
Advanced .gitignore Management: Global vs. Local templates, untracking previously tracked files, and securing API keys
Code Review Ethics: Identifying logic errors, maintaining style consistency, and fostering a positive developer culture
Conflict Resolution in the PR UI: Using the web-based editor to resolve simple merge conflicts
activities: The 'PR Ping-Pong': Students pair up, fork each other's repositories, propose a change, and perform a formal code review with at least two requested revisions
Global Gitignore Setup: Configuring a system-wide .gitignore to exclude .DS_Store or IDE-specific folders across all future projects
Final Project Sprint: A time-boxed group activity where 3-4 students contribute small components to a centralized repository using strict branching conventions
resources: GitHub Guides: 'Understanding the GitHub Flow'
Git-SCM Documentation: 'Distributed Workflows'
gitignore.io (Toptal tool) for automated ignore file generation
Sample 'Code Review Checklist' PDF
citations: Chacon, S., & Straub, B. (2014). Pro Git (2nd ed.). Apress.
GitHub, Inc. (2023). 'About pull requests.' GitHub Docs.
Atlassian. (2023). 'Gitflow Workflow.' Bitbucket Tutorials.

lessons.title: Collaborative Workflows and Pull Requests
objectives: Execute a full Gitflow or GitHub flow lifecycle including feature branching and merging
Participate in constructive code reviews via Pull Requests (PRs)
Configure project-specific .gitignore files to manage environment-sensitive data
Demonstrate collaborative proficiency through a final integrated project build
content_outline: Introduction to Workflow Patterns: Forking (Open Source) vs. Shared Repository Branching (Internal Teams)
Deep Dive into GitHub Flow: Feature branches, PR creation, and the 'Ship/Show/Ask' philosophy
Principles of Pull Request Etiquette: Writing meaningful descriptions and responding to feedback
Advanced .gitignore Management: Global vs. Local templates, untracking previously tracked files, and securing API keys
Code Review Ethics: Identifying logic errors, maintaining style consistency, and fostering a positive developer culture
Conflict Resolution in the PR UI: Using the web-based editor to resolve simple merge conflicts
activities: The 'PR Ping-Pong': Students pair up, fork each other's repositories, propose a change, and perform a formal code review with at least two requested revisions
Global Gitignore Setup: Configuring a system-wide .gitignore to exclude .DS_Store or IDE-specific folders across all future projects
Final Project Sprint: A time-boxed group activity where 3-4 students contribute small components to a centralized repository using strict branching conventions
resources: GitHub Guides: 'Understanding the GitHub Flow'
Git-SCM Documentation: 'Distributed Workflows'
gitignore.io (Toptal tool) for automated ignore file generation
Sample 'Code Review Checklist' PDF
citations: Chacon, S., & Straub, B. (2014). Pro Git (2nd ed.). Apress.
GitHub, Inc. (2023). 'About pull requests.' GitHub Docs.
Atlassian. (2023). 'Gitflow Workflow.' Bitbucket Tutorials.

quality_score.feedback: The syllabus is highly effective, with a clear course objective that aligns well with the lessons. It progresses logically from foundational concepts to advanced collaborative workflows, covering essential Git commands and principles comprehensively. The lessons are well-structured with specific objectives and relevant topics, making it suitable for learners aiming to master Git. Minor enhancements could further improve clarity and completeness.
issues: The 'Final Project: Collaborative build' in Lesson 10 is listed as a topic but might be better presented as a separate capstone project or assessment module to distinguish it from instructional content.
Consider adding a brief mention or topic on Git hooks or advanced customization (e.g., aliases, configuration) to cover more advanced features, enhancing the 'mastering' aspect.

gaps_found: Lesson 8 on 'Rebasing and Rewriting History' appears before basic collaboration concepts like stashing/tagging (Lesson 9) and collaborative workflows (Lesson 10). This risky topic might be better positioned after students are comfortable with safer collaboration patterns.
No clear progression from individual to team workflows - seems to jump between concepts without establishing foundational workflows first.
No dedicated lesson on using Git with GUI tools or IDEs for beginners who might struggle with command-line only.
missing_prerequisites: Basic command-line/terminal navigation knowledge for students unfamiliar with shell commands
Simple file system concepts (directories, files, paths) for repository initialization context
Basic understanding of what a 'project' or 'codebase' means in software development
Why version control is necessary - concrete examples of problems it solves
unclear_concepts: What 'Git Architecture' means in Lesson 1 - too abstract for beginners
The difference between 'undoing mistakes' (Lesson 4) and 'rewriting history' (Lesson 8) isn't clear from titles
What 'stashing' actually is and when to use it (Lesson 9)
What a 'pull request' is (Lesson 10) - assumes GitHub/GitLab knowledge
Confusion between 'remote collaboration' (Lesson 7) and 'collaborative workflows' (Lesson 10) - seems redundant
recommendations: Add a prerequisite lesson on basic terminal commands and file management
Include concrete examples/scenarios showing why Git is needed before diving into architecture
Reorder lessons: move rebasing (Lesson 8) to after collaborative workflows (Lesson 10) or make it optional/advanced
Add a lesson on using Git with popular IDEs (VSCode, IntelliJ) for visual learners
Include practice exercises or projects that build throughout the course
Clarify the distinction between Git commands and platform features (GitHub/GitLab)
Add a glossary or concept map showing how topics relate to each other
